title: 106_hr515
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act". The Congress finds that in the 10 years from 1987 to 1996, nearly 2,200 children aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings in the United States. The US leads in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death compared to other industrialized countries. In the 10 years from 1987 to 1996, nearly 2,200 children aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings in the United States, which was 9 times greater than in 25 other industrialized countries combined. Additionally, nearly 8 times that number are treated annually in hospital emergency rooms in the United States for nonfatal unintentional gunshot wounds. Gunshot wounds most often involve handguns, and children as young as 3 years old are strong enough to fire most commercially available firearms. Children as young as 3 years old are strong enough to fire most commercially available handguns, with 25% of 3- to 4-year-olds and 70% of 5- to 6-year-olds having sufficient finger strength. Firearms are not subject to minimum safety standards in the United States, despite 74% of the population supporting safety regulation. States support safety regulation of the firearms industry, as many trigger locks are inadequate to prevent accidental discharge or children from accessing firearms. Regulation of handgun discharge protection products is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury will regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children. Regulations will establish a minimum safety standard for these products, including those permanently installed in handguns. The Secretary of the Treasury will regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children by establishing a minimum safety standard for these products. This standard will ensure that the products are of adequate quality and construction to prevent children from operating a handgun, and can only be removed with specific access methods provided by the manufacturer. Additionally, test protocols related to poison prevention packaging standards may be considered in developing this standard, with a deadline of 12 months for issuance. The Secretary will establish a safety standard for handgun discharge protection products within 12 months of this Act's enactment. The standard must be issued in final form within that timeframe and will take effect 6 months after issuance. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of a handgun discharge protection product that violates the Act. They can also require the recall, repair, or replacement of such products and provide notice of associated risks to the public. The Secretary can issue orders to prohibit non-compliant handgun discharge protection products and require actions such as repair, replacement, or recall. The manufacturer, dealers, and public must be informed of risks and steps to bring the product into compliance. The Secretary can issue orders to prohibit non-compliant handgun discharge protection products and require actions such as repair, replacement, or recall. In order to ensure compliance, the Secretary may inspect places where the products are manufactured, stored, or transported for commercial purposes. SEC. 5. UNLAWFUL ACTS. It will be illegal for licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers to sell handguns without the required discharge protection product. There is an exception for sales to government agencies. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. A warning label must be displayed on handgun packaging, stating the dangers of children accessing and operating handguns. It emphasizes the importance of keeping handguns locked and unloaded to prevent accidents. The warning label required for handguns must be displayed in a contrasting manner on packaging or descriptive materials. Handguns cannot be sold without the warning label affixed to them. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's unintentional or self-inflicted gunshot wound from a handgun they sold after the Act's effective date, resulting in death, serious injury, or medical treatment.

SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary may assess civil penalties up to $10,000 for violations of the Act, revoke federal firearms licenses for violations, and allow individuals to bring private actions for damages in court for violations. Private enforcement of the Act allows any interested person to bring a lawsuit in a US district court to enforce the Act or stop any violations. The court may award attorney's fees to the prevailing party. This remedy is in addition to other remedies under common law or federal/state law. Compliance with the Act is not necessary for private remedies. The Act allows for private enforcement through lawsuits in US district courts, with the possibility of attorney's fees awarded to the prevailing party. Compliance with the Act or any orders issued does not exempt liability under common law or State statutory law. The failure of the Secretary to take action authorized under the Act is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties may be imposed for knowingly violating provisions of the Act or regulations related to handgun discharge protection products. Violation of the Act regarding handgun discharge protection products can result in fines, imprisonment for up to 2 years, or both under title 18, United States Code. SEC. 9. NO EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not override State laws unless they are inconsistent with this Act, and only to the extent of the inconsistency. State laws providing greater protection to children regarding handguns are not considered inconsistent with this Act. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms such as "handgun discharge protection product," "children," "licensed importer," "licensed manufacturer," "licensed dealer," "Secretary," and "handgun" as per section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code.
